title: Research Presentation — Crafting the Final Draft
description: Students finalize their year-long research project by polishing their written report into a presentation-ready final draft. They incorporate feedback from peers and parents, refine thesis statements, and ensure citations are properly formatted. This is the capstone of the research process taught across the year.
instructions:
1. Review the research project rubric together, noting expectations for content, organization, evidence, and mechanics.
2. Have the student read their draft aloud to identify awkward phrasing, missing transitions, and unclear arguments.
3. Work through the paper section by section: introduction with thesis, body paragraphs with evidence, and conclusion.
4. Guide the student to strengthen topic sentences so each paragraph has a clear purpose.
5. Check that every claim is supported by at least one cited source — model how to fix unsupported statements.
6. Review the bibliography or works cited page for correct formatting.
7. Have the student revise for grammar, spelling, and punctuation using a proofreading checklist.
8. Create a clean final copy — typed or neatly handwritten.
9. Design a title page with the project title, student name, and date.
10. Celebrate the completion of a major academic milestone.
materials_needed: Clean paper or computer for final copy
Style guide or citation reference sheet

slides.heading: Research Presentation
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our big project! It's telling us we're finally getting to the really important part: taking all the research we've done this year and making it into a super polished final paper that's ready to be presented. Think of it as putting the finishing touches on a masterpiece.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up a quiet workspace with the draft, all research notes, and reference materials easily accessible.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide is our "getting ready" checklist. We've got your research paper draft, which is the main thing. The proofreading checklist is like a detective's guide to find any mistakes. A red pen is for marking those mistakes, and then you'll need some clean paper or your computer to write the corrected version. The citation reference sheet is super important for making sure we give credit where credit is due. Go grab everything and find a comfy, quiet spot to work.

slides.text: Review the rubric together. Your final paper needs a strong thesis, organized paragraphs with evidence, proper citations, and polished mechanics. Let's make sure you hit every mark.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about making sure we know the rules for a great paper. The rubric is basically a score card that tells us exactly what your teacher is looking for, like having a super clear main idea (that's your thesis!), organizing your thoughts logically, using evidence to prove your points, and making sure there are no spelling or grammar oopsies. We're going to look it over together so you know exactly how to ace it.

slides.text: Read your entire draft aloud. When something sounds awkward or unclear, mark it with your red pen. Hearing your own words helps you catch things your eyes miss.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is a super cool trick for catching mistakes. You're going to read your whole paper out loud, just like you're telling a story. When you hear a sentence that sounds weird, or a part that doesn't make sense, that's when you grab your red pen and mark it. It's amazing how much you can catch just by listening to yourself.

slides.text: Now work section by section. Does your introduction hook the reader and clearly state your thesis? Does each body paragraph have a topic sentence, evidence, and analysis?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're diving into the actual writing, section by section. We'll start with your introduction to make sure it grabs the reader's attention and clearly tells them what your whole paper is about – that's your thesis! Then, we'll go through each paragraph to make sure it has a clear point and uses the research you found to back it up.

slides.text: Check every factual claim in your paper. Is it supported by a source? If not, either find a source or remove the claim. Scholars always back up their arguments.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a really important step for making your research sound super smart and believable. We're going to check every single fact or idea you mention. If you say something like "Penguins live in the Arctic," we need to make sure you have a source that says that. If you don't have proof, we either need to find it or take that sentence out.

slides.prompt: Revise your entire research paper using the proofreading checklist. Fix grammar, strengthen transitions, verify citations, and create your polished final draft with a title page.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this is where you get to shine and make your paper perfect! You'll use that checklist we talked about to go through everything – fixing any grammar errors, making sure your sentences flow smoothly from one to the next, double-checking all those citations, and finally creating that super clean, final version of your paper. Don't forget to add a cool title page too!

slides.text: You have completed a genuine research paper — from choosing a topic, to gathering sources, to writing and revising. This is real academic work that prepares you for middle school and beyond.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student produce a polished research paper with a clear thesis, cited evidence, organized structure, and correct mechanics?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! Seriously, finishing a whole research paper is a huge accomplishment, like climbing a mountain. You took an idea, found information, wrote it all down, and made it amazing. This is exactly the kind of work you'll do in middle school and beyond, and you absolutely crushed it.

parent_notes: This is the culmination of research skills developed all year. The student should feel proud of producing a substantial piece of academic writing. Resist the urge to rewrite their work — the goal is a student-produced paper, not a parent-perfected one. Help them use the proofreading checklist systematically rather than trying to fix everything at once. If your child is typing, this is a good opportunity to teach basic formatting skills (margins, font size, page numbers). Save this paper as part of their portfolio — it demonstrates significant growth in writing, research, and critical thinking.

title: Comprehensive Review — Fractions, Decimals, and Percentages
description: Students revisit the interconnected world of fractions, decimals, and percentages through a comprehensive review that ties together concepts learned across the year. They practice converting between forms, solving real-world problems, and explaining their reasoning. This review prepares them for the math portfolio.
instructions:
1. Create a 'Conversion Triangle' poster showing fractions, decimals, and percentages at each corner with arrows showing how to convert between them.
2. Review fraction operations: addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division of fractions with unlike denominators.
3. Practice decimal operations: place value, ordering, and all four operations with decimals.
4. Work through percentage problems: finding percentages of numbers, calculating discounts and tips.
5. Present mixed problems that require converting between forms (e.g., 'Which is greater: 3/8, 0.4, or 35%?').
6. Solve 5 real-world problems that integrate all three concepts (shopping scenarios, recipes, statistics).
7. Have the student create their own 'challenge problem' for each conversion type.
8. Review any areas where the student shows hesitation — these become study targets.
9. Record mastery levels for each skill on a self-assessment chart.
10. Discuss how these skills connect to everyday adult math.

slides.heading: The Big Review
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing our big review session! We're going to spend some time looking at fractions, decimals, and percentages, and how they're all connected. Think of it like a math superpower training, getting you ready for anything.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare 10-15 review problems spanning all three topics. Have manipulatives available for students who need concrete support.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this next part, we need a few things to help us out. We've got poster paper and markers for making a cool visual, some fraction pieces that are like building blocks for numbers, a calculator for checking our work, graph paper for neat drawings, and a chart to keep track of what we've mastered. Your grown-up can help you gather these supplies.

slides.text: Let's build a Conversion Triangle. Fractions, decimals, and percentages are three ways of saying the same thing. Draw arrows showing how to convert between each pair.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about building a "Conversion Triangle" to help us remember how fractions, decimals, and percentages are basically different ways of writing the same value. We'll draw our triangle, put each form at a corner, and then draw arrows to show the steps for changing from one to another, like a secret code.

slides.text: Now let's warm up with fractions. Solve these: 2/3 + 5/6, 7/8 - 1/4, 3/5 x 2/3, and 4/5 divided by 2/10. Show your work and explain each step.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to do some fraction practice, like warming up our math muscles. We'll add, subtract, multiply, and divide different fractions, making sure to show how we get our answers. It's like solving mini-puzzles to get ready for the bigger challenges.

slides.text: Switch to decimals: 3.75 + 2.086, 10.5 - 3.875, 2.4 x 0.15, and 7.2 divided by 0.9. Line up those decimal points carefully.
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to switch gears to decimals! We'll practice adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing numbers with decimal points, just like you see when you're dealing with money. The key here is to keep those decimal points lined up nice and straight.

slides.text: Now percentages: What is 35% of 240? If a $65 jacket is 20% off, what do you pay? You scored 47 out of 55 — what percentage is that?
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide focuses on percentages, which are super useful for things like sales or figuring out scores. We'll calculate a percentage of a number, figure out how much something costs after a discount, and even turn a score into a percentage.

slides.prompt: Complete the mixed review challenge: 10 problems that require you to convert and calculate across fractions, decimals, and percentages. Then create 3 original challenge problems of your own.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where we put it all together! You'll tackle 10 problems that mix fractions, decimals, and percentages, so you'll need to decide which form is best for each one. After that, you get to be the teacher and create three of your own challenge problems for me!

slides.text: Fractions, decimals, and percentages are everywhere — in cooking, shopping, sports statistics, and science. You now have the tools to work fluently across all three forms.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student fluently convert between fractions, decimals, and percentages and apply all three to solve real-world problems?
slides.mascot_explanation: We're wrapping up our review, and it's awesome how much you've accomplished! You've learned how fractions, decimals, and percentages are all related and how to switch between them. This is super useful for everything from cooking to understanding sports stats, and you've definitely got the skills to use them confidently.

parent_notes: This comprehensive review should feel like a confidence-building exercise, not a test. If your child struggles with specific conversions, note them for targeted practice but don't dwell on frustration. The Conversion Triangle poster becomes a reference tool they can keep. Real-world problems are especially important — ask your child to calculate tips at restaurants, discounts while shopping, or recipe adjustments this week. For middle school readiness, fluency with these three representations is essential. The self-assessment chart helps your child take ownership of their learning.

title: Year-End Timeline Project — Planning the Illustrated Timeline
description: Students begin their capstone history project: a comprehensive illustrated timeline spanning from ancient civilizations through the modern era. They plan the layout, select key events from each period studied this year, and determine the scale and artistic approach for their timeline.
instructions:
1. Explain the capstone project: 'You will create an illustrated timeline that tells the story of human civilization — from ancient times to today.'
2. Review the major periods studied this year: ancient civilizations (Q1), medieval and Renaissance (Q2), modern era through World Wars and Civil Rights (Q3), and globalization (Q4).
3. Brainstorm a list of 20-30 key events the student wants to include, ensuring coverage across all periods.
4. Decide on the timeline format: horizontal scroll, accordion fold, wall display, or digital presentation.
5. Calculate the scale: how many years per inch or centimeter to fit everything.
6. Sketch a rough layout showing where each era will go and how much space it needs.
7. Plan the artistic elements: illustrations, maps, portraits, or symbols for each event.
8. Create a materials list and work schedule for completing the timeline over the next three weeks.
9. Begin selecting or sketching images for the first section (ancient civilizations).
10. Set a goal for what will be completed by the next history session.
materials_needed: Long butcher paper or poster boards
History notebooks and notes from the year

slides.heading: The Great Timeline
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this first slide is like the title page for your super cool history project! It's called "The Great Timeline," and it's basically telling you that you're going to be planning out a giant project that covers all of history. Think of it as the grand opening to your own history museum!

slides.setup_instructions: Gather all history materials from the year. Clear a large workspace — the floor may work best for planning a long timeline.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is showing you all the stuff you'll need for your timeline project. You've got the big paper (butcher paper or poster boards) to draw on, rulers to make straight lines, your history notebooks with all the info you learned, colored pencils and markers to make it look awesome, reference pictures to help you draw, and sticky notes for jotting down ideas. Go grab all these things with a grown-up so you're ready to go!

slides.text: This is your biggest history project of the year. You will create an illustrated timeline that tells the story of human civilization — everything we have studied from ancient times to today.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the main idea for your big project: you're going to create your very own illustrated timeline. It's going to tell the whole story of humans, from way back in ancient times all the way up to what's happening now, using pictures and drawings to show what happened. It's like making your own history book, but way more visual!

slides.text: Let's start by listing the major events. Look through your history notes from each quarter. Choose the events that YOU think were most important and interesting. Aim for 20-30 events.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's start picking out the most important moments in history. You'll look through all the notes you took this year, from ancient Egypt and Rome to more recent times. Think about which events you found most interesting or important, and write down about 20 to 30 of them to put on your timeline.

slides.text: Now decide your format. A long scroll? Accordion-folded paper? A wall display? Consider how much space you need and where you will display the finished product.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about how your timeline will look and feel. Will it be a long scroll that unrolls, or maybe folded like an accordion? You could even hang it on your wall or make it digital. Think about how much space you have and where you want to show it off when it's done.

slides.text: Calculate your scale. If your timeline covers 5,000 years and your paper is 10 feet long, that is about 500 years per foot. Mark the major eras on your rough layout.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's where we figure out how to fit everything. Imagine your timeline is a road – you need to decide how much of that road represents each year. If your timeline covers thousands of years, you'll figure out how many years fit into each inch or foot of your paper, and then mark where the different history periods will go.

slides.prompt: Create your detailed timeline plan: list of events, chosen format, scale calculations, rough layout sketch, and work schedule. Begin sketching the first section covering ancient civilizations.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is your chance to get creative and start putting it all together! You'll make a plan that includes your list of events, how you want your timeline to look, your scale measurements, a quick sketch of the layout, and a schedule for when you'll work on it. Then, you’ll start drawing the first part, all about ancient civilizations.

slides.text: You are now a historian telling the story of humanity. Over the next weeks, you will bring this timeline to life with illustrations, captions, and connections. This is YOUR story of the world.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student select historically significant events, organize them chronologically, and plan a coherent visual timeline with appropriate scale?
slides.mascot_explanation: Awesome job! You've just planned out how to tell the whole story of human history. Over the next few weeks, you'll add cool pictures and details to make your timeline amazing. You're officially a historian, creating your very own visual journey through time!

parent_notes: The illustrated timeline is a powerful synthesis project that connects everything your child learned in history this year. Let them choose which events to include — their selections reveal what resonated most. The planning phase is crucial; resist rushing to the 'fun' art part. Help with scale calculations if needed, but let the student make creative decisions about layout and design. This project will continue through week 36, so pace the work across sessions. Display the finished timeline prominently — it represents a year of historical learning and makes an impressive portfolio piece.

title: Capstone Atlas Project — Designing a Thematic World Atlas
description: Students begin their geography capstone: creating a personal thematic atlas that synthesizes the year's learning about physical, cultural, economic, political, and environmental geography. They plan which themes to feature, design the table of contents, and begin drafting their first thematic map.
instructions:
1. Introduce the capstone: 'You will create your own thematic atlas — a book of maps that each tell a different story about our world.'
2. Review the types of geography studied this year: physical features, climate, culture, economics, politics, and environment.
3. Brainstorm at least 8 thematic maps to include (e.g., world biomes, population density, major religions, trade routes, endangered habitats).
4. Design a table of contents page organizing the maps in a logical order.
5. Choose an atlas format: bound booklet, folder with loose pages, or digital slides.
6. Discuss cartographic elements every map needs: title, legend, compass rose, scale, and labels.
7. Begin the first map — a physical world map showing major landforms, mountain ranges, and bodies of water.
8. Sketch the map outline lightly in pencil before adding details.
9. Add color coding and create a comprehensive legend.
10. Set goals for completing one thematic map per session over the coming weeks.

slides.heading: My World Atlas
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just the cover page for our big project! It introduces our goal: to create our very own "Thematic Atlas," which is basically a special book of maps that each tell a unique story about different parts of the world. Think of it like designing your own collection of maps that show cool facts about Earth.

slides.setup_instructions: Print several blank world map outlines. Gather all geography work from the year for reference. Prepare a booklet or folder for the atlas.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide lists everything we'll need for our atlas project. We've got blank world map outlines – these are like the blank canvases for our maps. An atlas or globe will be super helpful for looking up real-world information. Colored pencils and a ruler will help us make our maps look awesome and accurate. Finally, a blank booklet or folder is where we'll put all our finished maps together, and we'll need our old geography notes to remember all the cool stuff we've learned this year.

slides.text: Professional geographers create atlases — books of maps that each tell a different story about our world. Now it is YOUR turn to create your own thematic atlas.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about understanding what an atlas is. Professional mapmakers, called geographers, create these awesome books of maps that each focus on a specific topic, like where different animals live or where big cities are. Today, you get to be the geographer and start making your own unique atlas that shows the stories *you* want to tell about the world.

slides.text: Think about everything we studied in geography this year. What themes could you map? Brainstorm at least 8 ideas: landforms, climate zones, population, religions, trade, languages, endangered species, natural resources...
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to brainstorm all the cool map ideas for our atlas! Think back to all the different things we've learned about our planet – like mountains, deserts, how many people live in different places, or even where different languages are spoken. We need to come up with at least eight different map themes that we want to include in our atlas to make it really interesting and informative.

slides.text: Design your table of contents. Organize your maps in a logical order — maybe start with physical geography and build toward human and environmental themes.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is like planning the table of contents for a book. You need to decide the order in which your maps will appear in your atlas. It makes sense to put them in a logical flow, maybe starting with the basic physical features of the Earth, then moving on to things like climate, population, or even how people use the land.

slides.text: Every map needs five elements: a title, a legend explaining colors and symbols, a compass rose, a scale, and clear labels. These make your map readable by anyone.
slides.mascot_explanation: Every good map needs a few key ingredients to make sense, and this slide lists them. You'll need a clear title so you know what the map is about, a legend that explains what all the colors and symbols mean, a compass rose to show directions, a scale to show distances, and labels for important places. These elements are like the instructions that help anyone understand your map.

slides.prompt: Create your atlas table of contents and begin your first thematic map — a physical world map showing major landforms, mountains, rivers, and oceans with a detailed legend.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where the real fun begins! You're going to start by designing the table of contents page, listing out all those cool map ideas we brainstormed. Then, you'll jump right into creating your very first map: a physical map showing all the big landforms like mountains, rivers, and oceans, and you'll need to make sure you include all those important map elements we just talked about, especially a really good legend.

slides.text: You are building something geographers create professionally — a thematic atlas. Each map you add will show a different layer of understanding about our world. By the end, your atlas will be a masterpiece.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student plan a multi-theme atlas, identify appropriate thematic categories, and create an accurate physical map with all required cartographic elements?
slides.mascot_explanation: You've just taken a huge step in creating your very own professional-style atlas! Think about it – you've planned out a whole book of maps and even started making your first one, showing off your understanding of the world's physical features. Each map you add from now on will build on this, creating an amazing collection that tells a unique story about our planet.

parent_notes: The thematic atlas is a substantial project that brings together the entire year of geography learning. It requires both knowledge (what to map) and skills (how to map it). Blank world map outlines can be printed from free online sources — having many copies allows for mistakes without stress. Each map should be progressively more complex. Encourage your child to refer back to their geography notes from each quarter. The atlas becomes a beautiful portfolio piece and reference tool. For students who enjoy digital tools, consider letting them create some maps using free mapping software as a bridge to middle school technology skills.

title: Wonder by R.J. Palacio — Meeting August Pullman
description: Begin reading 'Wonder' by R.J. Palacio, the story of August Pullman, a boy with facial differences who attends school for the first time in fifth grade. The opening chapters establish Auggie's world, his family, and the courage it takes to face a new environment. Students explore themes of kindness, empathy, and choosing to be kind.
instructions:
1. Introduce the book: 'Wonder' tells the story of Auggie, a boy who looks different from everyone else. It is about how one person's courage can change a whole community.
2. Read chapters 1-4 aloud (approximately 30 pages), pausing to discuss Auggie's perspective.
3. After chapter 1, discuss: 'Auggie says he is ordinary inside. What does he mean by that?'
4. Notice the first-person narration — how does hearing Auggie's own voice affect how we feel about him?
5. Discuss the family dynamics: how do Auggie's parents and sister each respond to his situation?
6. Explore the theme of 'precepts' that Mr. Browne introduces — what are precepts and why do they matter?
7. Ask: 'Have you ever been the new person somewhere? How did it feel?'
8. Connect to the Montessori value of respect for all people.
9. Have the student write a response: 'What would you want Auggie to know if he were coming to your school?'
10. Preview the next reading session and invite the student to read ahead independently.

slides.heading: Wonder
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the very first slide, and it's just introducing us to the book we're about to read, called "Wonder." It tells us the main character's name is August Pullman, or Auggie for short. So, this is like the cover page for our reading adventure!

slides.setup_instructions: Find a comfortable reading spot. Have the reading journal ready for notes and responses.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so for this part, we need to gather our supplies. We've got the book "Wonder" itself, which is our main tool. Then we need a reading journal – think of it like a special notebook for our thoughts about the story – and a pencil to write with. Make sure you find a comfy spot to read so you can really get into the story.

slides.text: We are starting a very special book. 'Wonder' is about a boy named Auggie who was born with facial differences. He has had 27 surgeries. Now, for the first time, he is going to school.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is telling us what the book is all about. It's the story of Auggie, a kid who looks different from other kids because of how he was born, and he's about to start school for the very first time. It's a big step for him, and the book is going to show us what that's like.

slides.text: As we read, listen for Auggie's voice. He tells his own story. Pay attention to how he sees himself versus how others see him.
slides.mascot_explanation: As we start reading, pay close attention to how Auggie talks about himself. He's telling the story in his own words, so we're hearing everything from his point of view. It's important to notice how he sees himself and then think about how other people might see him differently.

slides.text: Auggie says, 'I know I am not an ordinary ten-year-old kid.' But he also says he does ordinary things. What makes someone ordinary or extraordinary?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a question to get us thinking about Auggie. He says he's not an ordinary kid, but he also does ordinary things. So, what do you think makes someone ordinary? Is it how they look, or what they do, or something else?

slides.text: Mr. Browne gives the class a precept: 'When given the choice between being right or being kind, choose kind.' What do you think about that? When might being right and being kind conflict?
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide introduces a cool idea called a "precept" from Auggie's teacher, Mr. Browne. His precept is about choosing kindness over being right, which is a really important lesson. We need to think about when it might be hard to choose kindness, especially if you really want to prove you're right about something.

slides.prompt: In your reading journal, write a letter to Auggie. What would you want him to know if he were coming to your school or community? What would you do to make him feel welcome?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be creative! You're going to write a letter in your reading journal to Auggie. Imagine he was coming to your school – what would you say to him? What kind things could you do to make sure he felt like he belonged and was welcome?

slides.text: Auggie's story reminds us that everyone has an inner world that others cannot see. The choice to be kind — even when it is hard — is one of the most important choices we make every day.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify Auggie's perspective, discuss the theme of kindness versus judgment, and articulate empathetic responses to the text?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the end of our first session with "Wonder," and it's reminding us of the big message. Auggie's story shows us that everyone has a whole world inside them that we can't always see, and that choosing to be kind, even when it's tough, is super important. You did a great job thinking about Auggie and how to make him feel welcome!

parent_notes: Wonder is a deeply moving book that naturally sparks conversations about empathy, bullying, and the courage to be kind. It may bring up questions about disabilities, facial differences, or times your child felt excluded. Welcome these conversations — they are some of the most important discussions the year will hold. The book uses multiple narrators across its chapters, which is a sophisticated literary technique. This first session focuses on Auggie's perspective; later sessions will show how other characters experience the same events. Encourage your child to read ahead if they are captivated — this book tends to be hard to put down.

title: Creative Writing Anthology — Selecting and Revising Best Works
description: Students curate a personal creative writing anthology by selecting their best pieces from the entire year. They review stories, poems, essays, and creative pieces, choosing works that represent their growth and voice as a writer. Selected pieces are revised for publication in a bound anthology.
instructions:
1. Gather all creative writing from the year — stories, poems, journal entries, essays, and any other original writing.
2. Read through everything and sort into three piles: 'Definitely include,' 'Maybe include,' and 'Not this time.'
3. Discuss what makes a piece worth including: personal meaning, quality of writing, demonstration of growth, or creative risk.
4. Aim to select 8-12 pieces for the anthology.
5. For each selected piece, decide: Does it need light revision (editing) or deeper revision (rewriting sections)?
6. Begin revising the first 3-4 selected pieces, focusing on strengthening openings and endings.
7. Plan the order of pieces in the anthology — chronological, thematic, or genre-based.
8. Draft an 'About the Author' page.
9. Brainstorm a title for the anthology that reflects the student's identity as a writer.
10. Create a revision schedule to polish all pieces before binding.
materials_needed: All creative writing from the year

slides.heading: My Writing Anthology
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover page for your whole project. It's introducing the idea that you're going to put together a special book, like a collection of your greatest hits, all of your best writing from this whole year. Think of it like a music artist releasing an album of their top songs – you're doing the same thing with your stories and poems!

items: All creative writing from the year
slides.setup_instructions: Spread out all creative writing from the year on a large surface. Sort by type or date if possible.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide is telling you what you'll need for this project. You've got all your writing from the year, which is awesome! You'll also want a folder to keep things neat, a red pen for making notes, some clean paper for any edits, and sticky notes to mark up your work. Make sure you have all this stuff ready before you dive in!

slides.text: Professional authors publish 'collected works' — their best writing gathered in one volume. Today, you become the editor of your own anthology. Spread out everything you have written this year.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is like being a museum curator, but for your own writing. You're going to spread out all the amazing things you've written this year, just like an author would gather their best work to show off. It's all about getting a good look at everything you've created.

slides.text: Read through your writing. Some pieces will still make you feel proud; others might surprise you with how much you have grown since writing them. Sort into three piles: yes, maybe, and not this time.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to go through everything you've written and be a bit of a judge. As you read, think about which pieces really shine and make you feel proud, or maybe ones that show how much you've gotten better. You'll sort them into three piles: definitely keep, maybe keep, and probably not this time.

slides.text: For your 'yes' pile, decide what each piece needs. Some may just need spelling and grammar fixes. Others might need a stronger ending or more descriptive language. Mark them with sticky notes.
slides.mascot_explanation: For the pieces you decided to keep, we need to make them even better. This slide is telling you to look closely at each one and figure out what it needs – maybe it just needs a quick spelling check, or perhaps a whole new ending or some more descriptive words to make it pop. Use those sticky notes to mark what kind of changes each piece needs.

slides.text: Plan your anthology's order. Will you organize by genre (poems first, then stories)? By theme? Chronologically to show your growth? There is no wrong answer — it is YOUR book.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the designer of your book! Think about how you want people to read your anthology. You could put all your poems together, or maybe arrange your stories by when you wrote them to see how you've grown. It's totally up to you how you want to order everything, so pick what makes the most sense to you.

slides.prompt: Select 8-12 pieces for your anthology, begin revising the first 3-4, draft your 'About the Author' page, and choose a title for your collection.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is the big activity where you put it all together! You'll pick your favorite 8 to 12 pieces, start fixing up the first few by making their beginnings and endings stronger, write a little something about yourself for the "About the Author" page, and come up with a cool title for your whole collection. You've got 25 minutes to get a good start on all of this!

slides.text: You have a year's worth of creative writing — that is a real accomplishment. Your anthology will preserve these pieces and show the world the writer you have become.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student critically evaluate their own writing, select pieces based on quality and significance, and revise selected works for improvement?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at everything you've done! You've gathered a whole year's worth of your writing, picked out the best parts, and made them even better. This anthology is proof of how much you've grown as a writer, and it’s a super cool way to share your voice with the world.

parent_notes: The writing anthology is a powerful portfolio piece and a gift your child can treasure for years. Resist the urge to influence their selections — the pieces they choose reveal what matters to them as writers. Some may choose based on quality, others on emotional significance. Both approaches are valid. When revising, help your child see that revision is not punishment but an act of caring about their work. The 'About the Author' page is a fun exercise in self-reflection. Consider printing and binding the anthology as a summer keepsake, or creating a digital version to share with family.

title: Comprehensive Review — Pre-Algebra and Algebraic Thinking
description: Students review the pre-algebra concepts introduced throughout the year, including variables, expressions, equations, inequalities, and patterns. They solve equations, translate word problems into algebraic expressions, and explore how algebraic thinking connects to all other math they have learned.
instructions:
1. Review the concept of variables — letters that stand for unknown numbers — and why algebra is useful.
2. Practice translating words into algebraic expressions: 'five more than a number' = n + 5.
3. Solve one-step equations: x + 7 = 15, 3n = 24, y - 9 = 11, m/4 = 6.
4. Solve two-step equations: 2x + 3 = 11, 4n - 5 = 19.
5. Review order of operations (PEMDAS) with expressions that include parentheses and exponents.
6. Explore inequalities: graph x > 3 and x ≤ 7 on number lines.
7. Identify and extend patterns using algebraic rules (e.g., the rule for 2, 5, 8, 11... is 3n - 1).
8. Solve 5 word problems that require setting up and solving equations.
9. Have the student rate their confidence with each skill on a 1-5 scale.
10. Identify any areas needing additional practice before the math portfolio.

slides.heading: Algebra Review
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our big math adventure today. It's called "Algebra Review," and it tells us we'll be looking at variables (which are just letters standing in for numbers), equations (like number sentences with an equals sign), and patterns. Think of it as getting ready to understand a secret code that helps us solve all sorts of problems.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a set of practice equations at varying difficulty levels. Have algebra tiles available for concrete support.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is showing us the tools we'll be using today. We've got algebra tiles or counters – those are like little blocks that help us see what's happening in an equation. The number line and graph paper are for drawing out our answers, especially for inequalities. The self-assessment chart is where you'll tell me how you feel about each skill, and the word problem cards have fun challenges for us. Go grab these with a grown-up if you need to!

slides.text: Algebra is the language of patterns and relationships. A variable is just a letter that holds a place for a number we need to find. Let's review how to 'speak algebra.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about understanding the basic idea of algebra. Algebra is super useful because it's like a universal language for math that helps us describe patterns and relationships we see everywhere, from how many cookies are left to how fast a car is going. A variable is just a placeholder, like a box with a question mark, for a number we don't know yet, and we're going to learn how to figure out what number goes in that box.

slides.text: Translate these into algebra: 'A number plus 8 equals 20.' 'Three times a number is 27.' 'A number divided by 5 is less than 4.' Write the expression or equation for each.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to practice turning regular English sentences into math language, which is called translating. For example, if someone says "five more than a number," we can write that as 'n + 5' where 'n' is our unknown number. Your job here is to take those phrases like 'a number plus 8 equals 20' and write them down using numbers and letters, just like we practiced.

slides.text: Solve these equations step by step, showing your work. Remember: whatever you do to one side, you must do to the other. Use algebra tiles if it helps you visualize the balance.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we start solving! You'll see a few equations, and your goal is to find the value of the letter (the variable) that makes the equation true. Remember the golden rule: whatever you do to one side of the equals sign, you *must* do to the other side to keep it balanced, just like a seesaw. If you get stuck, the algebra tiles can help you literally see how to keep things balanced.

slides.text: Now let's look at patterns. What is the rule for this sequence: 4, 7, 10, 13, 16...? Can you write it as an algebraic expression? Use the rule to predict the 20th term.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is all about spotting patterns, which is a huge part of algebra! You'll look at a list of numbers and figure out the "rule" that connects them – like how you add 3 each time to get from one number to the next in the sequence 4, 7, 10... Once you find that rule, you can use it to predict what number would come way, way down the line, like the 20th number.

slides.prompt: Complete the pre-algebra review: solve 10 equations (mix of one-step and two-step), graph 3 inequalities, find rules for 3 patterns, and solve 5 algebra word problems.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is our main activity where we put everything we've learned into practice! You'll solve a mix of equations, draw inequalities on a number line, figure out the rules for a few number patterns, and tackle some word problems by turning them into algebra. You've got 25 minutes, so pace yourself and remember all the tricks we've talked about.

slides.text: Algebraic thinking is the bridge to middle school math. You are already solving equations and finding patterns — that IS algebra. You are more ready for middle school math than you might think.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student solve one-step and two-step equations, translate words into algebraic expressions, graph inequalities, and identify pattern rules?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at everything you've just done! This slide reminds us that all this stuff – solving equations, figuring out patterns, using letters for numbers – is the foundation for all the cool math you'll do in middle school. You've shown you can handle these skills, and that means you're totally ready for what's next!

parent_notes: Pre-algebra can feel intimidating, but your child has been building toward it all year. The key insight is that algebra is just a formalization of the logical thinking they already do. If they struggle, go back to concrete materials — algebra tiles make abstract equations visible. The self-assessment is important: students who can accurately identify their own strengths and weaknesses are better prepared for independent middle school learning. Focus on the word problems especially, as translating real situations into equations is the most practical algebra skill.

title: Science Fair Preparation — Finalizing the Presentation Board
description: Students complete their science fair presentation boards, organizing their experiment results, data analysis, and conclusions into a clear, visual display. They practice the scientific method's final steps: communicating results and drawing conclusions based on evidence.
instructions:
1. Review the science fair board layout: Title, Question, Hypothesis, Materials, Procedure, Data/Results, Analysis, Conclusion.
2. Check that each section is complete and clearly written — edit for clarity and accuracy.
3. Create data displays: graphs, charts, or tables that visually represent experimental results.
4. Write a clear conclusion that addresses the original hypothesis — was it supported or refuted?
5. Add photographs or drawings of the experiment in progress.
6. Ensure the board is visually appealing: consistent fonts, neat labels, balanced layout.
7. Add any necessary acknowledgments (people who helped, sources consulted).
8. Create a brief abstract (3-5 sentences summarizing the entire project).
9. Practice the oral presentation: 3-minute explanation of the project.
10. Peer or parent review: get feedback on clarity and completeness.
materials_needed: Index cards for oral presentation notes

slides.heading: Science Fair Board
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is all about your science fair board, which is like the cover page for your whole project. It's going to show everyone what you discovered and how you did it, so it needs to look awesome and be super clear.

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out all sections on the board before gluing anything down. Step back and check the visual balance.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide is showing you all the stuff you need to build your science fair board. You've got the big board itself, all the pieces you printed out or wrote, glue, scissors, markers for decorating, any graphs you made, and some index cards for notes. Make sure you have all of this ready before you start sticking things down!

slides.text: Your display board tells the story of your experiment. A viewer should be able to understand your entire project just by reading the board, from left to right, top to bottom.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is super important because your board is basically telling the whole story of your experiment. Imagine someone walking up to it for the first time – they should be able to read it from top to bottom, left to right, and totally get what you did, what happened, and what you learned.

slides.text: Check each section: Is your question clear? Is your hypothesis specific and testable? Are your materials and procedure detailed enough that someone could repeat your experiment?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to double-check each part of your board to make sure it makes sense. We need to see if your experiment question is easy to understand, if your guess (your hypothesis) was really specific, and if you wrote down exactly what you used and what you did so someone else could do it too.

slides.text: Your data section is the most important. Create at least one graph or chart that shows your results visually. Label axes clearly and include units of measurement.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is all about your results, which is often the coolest part! You need to have at least one graph or chart that shows what happened in your experiment in a way that's easy to see. Make sure you label what the lines on your graph mean and what units you measured in, like inches or grams.

slides.text: Write your conclusion. Did your data support or refute your hypothesis? What did you learn? What would you do differently? What new questions emerged?
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to write your conclusion, which is where you wrap everything up. You'll explain if what happened in your experiment proved your original guess right or wrong, what you learned from the whole thing, and maybe even think about what you'd do differently next time or what new questions you have.

slides.prompt: Complete your display board with all required sections. Then practice your 3-minute oral presentation using index cards as notes. Time yourself and adjust for length.
slides.mascot_explanation: For this activity, you're going to put all the pieces of your board together and make sure everything looks neat and balanced. Then, grab those index cards and practice talking about your project for about 3 minutes – time yourself to make sure you're not going too fast or too slow.

slides.text: Communicating results is the final step of the scientific method — and arguably the most important. If a scientist discovers something but cannot explain it clearly, the discovery has limited impact.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student present a complete science fair board with all sections of the scientific method, clear data visualization, and a logical conclusion?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide is reminding us why sharing what you learned is so important in science. If you do an amazing experiment but can't explain it to others, it's like discovering treasure and not telling anyone! So, check if your board has all the parts, your data looks good, and your conclusion makes sense.

parent_notes: The science fair board is a major synthesis project. Help your child organize their sections before gluing — lay everything out first and check the visual flow. Graphs are often the hardest part; help with ruler-straight axes and even scaling if needed, but let the student plot their own data points. The oral presentation practice is crucial — most students need 3-5 rehearsals to feel comfortable. Ask questions a judge might ask: 'Why did you choose this topic? What was your biggest challenge? What would you investigate next?' This project demonstrates scientific thinking, communication skills, and perseverance.

title: End-of-Year Art Show — Curating Your Exhibition
description: Students begin preparing for their end-of-year art show by curating a selection of their best artwork from throughout the year. They learn about gallery curation, write artist statements, and plan the physical exhibition layout. This connects art-making to the professional art world.
instructions:
1. Discuss what an art curator does: selects, organizes, and presents artwork to tell a story or create an experience.
2. Gather all artwork created throughout the year and lay it out for review.
3. Select 10-15 pieces that represent the student's best work and artistic growth.
4. For each selected piece, write a small label: title, medium, date, and a one-sentence description.
5. Write an artist statement (3-5 sentences): Who are you as an artist? What themes do you explore? What media do you prefer?
6. Plan the exhibition layout: which pieces go where? Consider flow, visual contrast, and thematic groupings.
7. Decide on a title for the exhibition.
8. Create an invitation for family members to attend the art show.
9. Prepare any pieces that need matting, framing, or repair.
10. Discuss the timeline for installation and the show itself.

slides.heading: Your Art Exhibition
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is the title of our project – we're getting ready for our big art show! Think of it like planning your own mini-museum, where you get to be the boss and decide which of your amazing artwork will be on display.

slides.setup_instructions: Spread all artwork on a large surface or hang on a line with clips. Have labeling supplies and matting materials ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so we need a few things to make this art show happen. We need *all* the art you've made this year so we can pick the best, some card stock and markers for writing the little signs that go with each piece, construction paper if we need to make the artwork look extra sharp, and special paper for making invitations. It's like gathering all your tools before starting a cool project!

slides.text: A curator is someone who selects and arranges artwork for an exhibition. Today, you are the curator of YOUR art show. Your job is to choose the pieces, write about them, and plan how to display them.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about becoming an art curator, which is a super important job! A curator is like the director of an art show – they choose which art to show and how to arrange it so it tells a story or makes people feel something. Today, *you* are the curator for your own show!

slides.text: Look at all your art from this year. Select 10-15 pieces you are most proud of. Consider variety: different media, subjects, and styles. Think about showing your GROWTH as well as your best work.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to pick your superstars! Go through all the art you've created this year and choose about 10 to 15 pieces that you feel really proud of. Try to pick a variety of different things you made, and think about how much you've improved – that's showing your growth as an artist!

slides.text: Write an artist statement. This tells viewers who you are as an artist. What do you like to create? What inspires you? What have you learned this year? Three to five sentences is perfect.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to talk about yourself as an artist. Your artist statement is like a short introduction to your work. You'll write just a few sentences explaining what kind of art you love to make, what inspires you, and maybe what you've learned about art this year. It's your chance to let people know who you are through your art!

slides.text: Plan your exhibition. Group related pieces together. Think about visual flow — how will viewers move through the show? Create labels for each piece with the title, medium, and date.
slides.mascot_explanation: Planning the show is like arranging your favorite toys. Think about which pieces look good next to each other, and how you want people to walk through and see everything. You'll also make little signs, called labels, for each artwork that say its title, what it's made of, and when you finished it.

slides.prompt: Select your exhibition pieces, write labels for each one, compose your artist statement, design an exhibition invitation, and sketch a layout plan for the display.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is the fun part where you do the actual work! You’ll pick your best art pieces, write their labels, create your artist statement, design an invitation for your family, and even sketch out a plan for how everything will be displayed. You've got 25 minutes to bring it all together, so let's get started!

slides.text: You are not just an artist — you are a curator telling the story of your creative year. When your family sees this exhibition, they will see how much you have grown and what matters to you as an artist.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student critically evaluate their own artwork, write descriptive labels, compose an artist statement, and plan a coherent exhibition layout?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you've done an amazing job! You're not just an artist anymore; you're a curator who has carefully chosen and arranged your work to share your creative journey. When your family comes to the show, they'll see all your hard work and how much you've grown, and that's pretty awesome!

parent_notes: The art show is a wonderful celebration that validates your child's creative work all year. Help them find a space to display their art — a wall, a hallway, or even a table works. The artist statement is an exercise in self-reflection that many adult artists struggle with; celebrate whatever your child writes. Consider making the art show a real event with invited family members — children take tremendous pride in presenting their work formally. Take photos of the exhibition for the portfolio. This activity teaches curation, communication, and self-assessment alongside art appreciation.

title: Middle School Transition — Understanding What Changes
description: Students explore the differences between elementary and middle school through research, discussion, and reflection. They learn about new structures like lockers, class periods, multiple teachers, and increased independence. This lesson addresses both excitement and anxiety about the transition ahead.
instructions:
1. Begin with an open conversation: 'What do you know about middle school? What have you heard? What do you wonder?'
2. Create a T-chart: 'Elementary School' on one side and 'Middle School' on the other.
3. Discuss key differences: schedule structure, multiple teachers, lockers, homework expectations, social dynamics, and extracurricular options.
4. Address common concerns: getting lost, making friends, harder work, changing classes.
5. Identify skills the student ALREADY has that will help them succeed: organization, time management, self-directed learning, research skills.
6. Discuss what Montessori students bring to middle school that gives them an advantage: independence, curiosity, respect for others.
7. Create a 'What I Want to Know' list of remaining questions about middle school.
8. Research answers using age-appropriate resources or by contacting the middle school.
9. Write a 'Letter to My Future Middle School Self' with advice and encouragement.
10. Discuss who can help with the transition: parents, teachers, older students, school counselors.

slides.heading: Middle School Ahead
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure into middle school! It's telling us that we're going to explore all the big changes that happen when you move from elementary school to middle school, and it’s going to help us understand what that feels like. Think of it as getting ready for a new journey.

slides.setup_instructions: Create a relaxed, conversational atmosphere. This lesson is about open discussion, not lecture.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide is showing us the supplies we'll need for our middle school exploration. We've got a big piece of paper and markers to make something called a T-chart, which is just a way to compare two things side-by-side. We'll also need lined paper for writing, and if you have any papers or info about middle school already, grab those too.

slides.text: Middle school is an exciting new chapter. Let's talk honestly about what changes and what stays the same. First — what have you heard about middle school? What excites you? What worries you?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we start our chat! We're going to talk about middle school. Have you heard anything from friends or family? What sounds cool or exciting about it? And what parts might make you feel a little nervous? It's totally okay to have both feelings!

slides.text: Let's make a T-chart comparing elementary and middle school. In middle school, you will have different teachers for different subjects, a locker, more homework, and more freedom. But you still have lunch, recess, friends, and learning.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to make that T-chart we talked about. On one side, we'll write down things about elementary school, like having one main teacher. Then, on the other side, we'll write about middle school, like having different teachers for each subject, using a locker, and maybe having more homework. It's a way to see all the differences clearly.

slides.text: Here is the secret: you ALREADY have the skills you need. You know how to organize your work, manage your time, research independently, and ask good questions. Montessori prepared you for exactly this.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is super important because it’s reminding you of all the awesome skills you already have from elementary school, especially from Montessori! You know how to keep your stuff organized, get your work done, figure things out on your own, and ask smart questions. Those skills are like superpowers that will help you rock middle school.

slides.text: Write a letter to your future middle school self. What advice would today-you give to September-you? What strengths should you remember when things feel hard?
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to be a time traveler! We're going to write a letter to yourself, but for a future date. Think about what advice you’d give your future middle school self. What should you remember when things get tough, and what cool things should you look forward to?

slides.prompt: Complete the T-chart, write your list of questions about middle school, and compose your 'Letter to My Future Middle School Self.' Research answers to at least 3 of your questions.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the part where we put everything together. You'll finish that T-chart, write down any questions you still have about middle school, and finish your letter to your future self. Then, you'll pick at least three questions and try to find the answers, maybe by looking online or asking someone.

slides.text: Every older student once felt exactly like you do now — a mix of excitement and nervousness. That is completely normal. The skills and character you have built this year will serve you well in middle school and beyond.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify key differences between elementary and middle school, recognize their own preparedness, and articulate both concerns and excitement about the transition?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide is like a high-five for finishing! It's reminding us that it's totally normal to feel a mix of excited and nervous about middle school, because everyone does. You've learned a lot and built great skills, and those things will really help you out in middle school and beyond.

parent_notes: Transition anxiety is normal and valid. Listen more than you reassure — let your child express worries without immediately solving them. The T-chart exercise helps make the unknown concrete, which reduces anxiety. Emphasize the Montessori advantages: your child already practices self-directed learning, time management, and respectful communication — skills many middle schoolers are just learning. If possible, arrange a visit to the middle school or connect with a current student. The letter to their future self is powerful — save it and give it to them on the first day of middle school. Watch for signs of excessive anxiety and address them with patience.

title: Research Presentation — Preparing Visual Aids and Speaking Notes
description: Students create visual aids and speaking notes for their research presentation. They design slides or posters that enhance their talk without replacing it, practice the distinction between reading and presenting, and prepare to speak confidently about their research to an audience.
instructions:
1. Discuss the difference between a presentation and reading a paper aloud: presentations engage the audience visually and verbally.
2. Review the research paper and identify 5-7 key points that form the backbone of the presentation.
3. For each key point, design a visual aid: a slide, poster section, or prop that illustrates the point.
4. Apply the '5x5 rule' for slides/posters: no more than 5 bullet points, no more than 5 words each.
5. Include at least one graph, chart, image, or map in the visual aids.
6. Create speaking note cards — brief prompts, NOT full sentences to read.
7. Practice the presentation structure: introduction, main points, conclusion, questions.
8. Rehearse with a timer — aim for 8-10 minutes.
9. Practice eye contact, clear voice, and confident posture.
10. Do a full rehearsal for a family member and incorporate their feedback.
materials_needed: Poster board or computer for slides

slides.heading: Presentation Skills
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing what we're going to do: get ready to give a great presentation by making cool visual aids and simple notes. Think of it like getting your gear ready before an awesome game.

slides.setup_instructions: Have the completed research paper readily available. Set up the workspace for creating visual aids.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this part, we need to gather our tools. You'll need your research paper to know what to talk about, something to make your visuals on like a poster board or a computer, some index cards for your notes, markers to make things look good, and a timer to make sure you're not talking too long. Go grab those with a grown-up's help!

slides.text: A great presenter does not read to the audience — they TALK to the audience. Your visual aids support your words; they do not replace them. Think of slides or posters as illustrations, not scripts.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is super important because it tells you the secret to being a fantastic presenter. Instead of just reading a story, you want to *talk* to people like you're telling them something exciting. Your posters or slides are there to help people see what you're talking about, not to read the whole thing word-for-word.

slides.text: Identify the 5-7 most important points from your research. Each one gets its own visual — a slide, poster section, or prop. Use the 5x5 rule: 5 bullets max, 5 words each.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's think about what's most important in your research. Find the 5 to 7 biggest ideas you want your audience to remember. For each big idea, you'll make a visual, but here's the rule: keep it super short, like only 5 small points, and each point can only have 5 words. This keeps your audience focused on you!

slides.text: Create speaking note cards. Each card has a keyword or phrase — just enough to remind you what to say. Number your cards and keep them in order.
slides.mascot_explanation: Next, we're going to make these little note cards. These are just for *you* to remember what to say next, like a secret code. You'll write down just a word or two for each point, not whole sentences, so you don't get tempted to read them. Make sure they're numbered so you can put them back in order easily.

slides.text: Practice! Stand up, make eye contact with an imaginary audience, and speak clearly. Use your note cards as reminders, not scripts. Time yourself — aim for 8 to 10 minutes.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we practice making it real! You'll stand up like you're in front of people, pretend to look at them, and speak clearly. Use your note cards to remind you, but try to talk naturally. Set your timer for 8 to 10 minutes, because that's about how long a good presentation usually is.

slides.prompt: Create your visual aids (slides or posters), write speaking note cards, and rehearse your complete presentation at least twice. Time yourself and adjust as needed.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is the big activity where you put it all together! You'll create those visuals and note cards we talked about, and then you'll actually practice your whole talk at least twice. Make sure you time yourself each time and if you're going too fast or too slow, adjust what you say or how much you say.

slides.text: Presenting research is how scholars share their discoveries with the world. Every scientist, historian, and author must learn to speak about their work with confidence and clarity. You are ready.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student create effective visual aids that complement (not duplicate) their speech, use note cards for guidance, and deliver a timed presentation with eye contact and clear voice?
slides.mascot_explanation: You've done it! Making a presentation is how smart people share cool discoveries, like scientists showing off a new invention or authors sharing their stories. You've learned how to make awesome visuals, use notes to help you speak, and practice talking clearly and confidently. You're totally ready to share your research!

parent_notes: Presentation skills are among the most valuable skills for middle school and beyond. Many students are terrified of public speaking — this is normal. The key is preparation: the more they practice, the more confident they become. Be a supportive audience during rehearsals: give specific praise ('I liked how you explained the data') and gentle, actionable feedback ('Try looking up more during the introduction'). Do not correct content during presentation practice — focus only on delivery. The note card method prevents the common trap of reading the entire paper aloud. Consider recording a rehearsal so the student can self-evaluate.

title: Comprehensive Review — Geometry and Measurement
description: Students review geometry concepts from the year: classification of shapes, angle measurement, area and perimeter formulas, volume, coordinate graphing, and geometric transformations. They solve problems that require applying multiple geometry skills and prepare for the math portfolio.
instructions:
1. Create a 'Geometry Reference Sheet' summarizing all formulas and vocabulary learned this year.
2. Review shape classification: triangles by sides and angles, quadrilaterals, polygons, and circles.
3. Practice angle measurement and calculation: complementary, supplementary, and angles in triangles.
4. Review area formulas for rectangles, triangles, parallelograms, trapezoids, and circles.
5. Solve perimeter problems, including composite shapes.
6. Calculate volume of rectangular prisms and cylinders.
7. Review coordinate graphing: plotting points, identifying quadrants, finding distances.
8. Practice geometric transformations: translations, reflections, and rotations on the coordinate plane.
9. Solve 5 multi-step geometry problems that combine several skills.
10. Self-assess and identify areas for the math portfolio focus.

slides.heading: Geometry Review
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover page for our geometry adventure! It's showing us that we're going to be reviewing everything about shapes, how to measure them, and how to work with them on a graph. Think of it as a map for all the cool geometry stuff we've learned this year.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up a clean workspace with all geometry tools. Have formulas available for reference as students work.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is telling us what tools we'll need for our geometry work. We've got a protractor for measuring angles, a ruler for drawing straight lines and measuring length, a compass for drawing circles, graph paper for plotting points, a calculator for any tricky math, and colored pencils to make our work look awesome. Go grab all these things and set up a nice clear spot to work.

slides.text: Let's build a Geometry Reference Sheet — a personal cheat sheet with every formula and vocabulary word you have learned. This becomes a study tool you can keep.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about creating your own "cheat sheet" for geometry, which is super smart! You're going to write down all the important formulas and vocabulary words we've learned, like how to find the area of a rectangle or what an "acute angle" means. This sheet will be your personal guide to help you remember everything as we go through the review.

slides.text: Shapes first: classify these triangles as acute, right, or obtuse AND as equilateral, isosceles, or scalene. Then name these quadrilaterals and list their properties.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're diving into classifying shapes! First, you'll look at some triangles and decide if they have sharp angles (acute), one square corner (right), or a wide angle (obtuse), and then see if all their sides are different (scalene), two are the same (isosceles), or all three are the same (equilateral). After that, you’ll name some four-sided shapes (quadrilaterals) and list their special features.

slides.text: Now measurement: find the area and perimeter of these shapes. Remember — area is the space inside (square units) and perimeter is the distance around (linear units).
slides.mascot_explanation: This part focuses on measurement! You'll be calculating two things for different shapes: the area, which is how much space is *inside* the shape, and the perimeter, which is the total distance *around* the outside edge. Remember, area is measured in square units like inches squared, while perimeter is just in regular units like inches.

slides.text: Coordinate geometry: plot these points, identify the quadrant, and find the distance between pairs. Then perform a reflection across the y-axis and a 90-degree rotation.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for the coordinate plane, which is like a giant number map! You'll be plotting points using their x and y numbers, figuring out which section (quadrant) they're in, and even finding out how far apart two points are. Then, you'll get to move shapes around by reflecting them (like looking in a mirror) and rotating them (like spinning them).

slides.prompt: Complete the geometry review: build your reference sheet, solve classification problems, calculate areas and perimeters of 6 shapes, find volumes of 3 solids, and complete 4 coordinate graphing tasks.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to put everything together! You'll be using all the tools and knowledge from the past few slides to complete a geometry challenge. Think of it like a fun mission where you'll build that reference sheet, sort shapes, measure them, figure out volumes, and do some cool coordinate graphing tricks, all within about 25 minutes.

slides.text: Geometry is everywhere — in architecture, art, engineering, and nature. Your reference sheet is a tool you can use anytime. Keep it in your math portfolio as a reminder of everything you have mastered.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student classify shapes, measure and calculate angles, apply area/perimeter/volume formulas, plot coordinates, and perform transformations?
slides.mascot_explanation: We've made it to the end! This slide is reminding us that geometry isn't just in math class; it's all around us in buildings, art, and even nature. Your reference sheet is a fantastic tool you can keep using, and by finishing this review, you've shown you've mastered a ton of important geometry skills, which you can now add to your math portfolio!

parent_notes: The Geometry Reference Sheet is a valuable study tool — encourage your child to make it thorough and visually clear. Geometry is one area where manipulatives and real-world connections really help: measure actual rooms for area, calculate the volume of containers, find angles in architecture. If your child struggles with formulas, connect each formula to a visual: area of a triangle is literally half of a rectangle cut diagonally. Coordinate graphing is especially important for middle school, where it leads directly into graphing equations. Make sure the reference sheet is saved in the math portfolio.

title: Oral History Interview — Preparing to Record Living History
description: Students learn the art of oral history by preparing to interview a family member, neighbor, or community member about their life experiences. They research oral history techniques, develop thoughtful questions, and practice active listening skills. This connects personal stories to the broader historical narrative.
instructions:
1. Discuss oral history: the practice of recording personal stories to preserve history that might otherwise be lost.
2. Watch or read an example of an oral history interview (StoryCorps or similar).
3. Choose an interview subject: a grandparent, older neighbor, community leader, or anyone with interesting life experiences.
4. Brainstorm categories of questions: childhood, historical events they witnessed, changes they have seen, lessons learned.
5. Write 15-20 open-ended questions (not yes/no) organized from easier to deeper topics.
6. Practice interviewing skills: active listening, follow-up questions, comfortable silence, not interrupting.
7. Test recording equipment (if using audio or video).
8. Conduct a practice interview with a parent or sibling.
9. Schedule the real interview with the chosen subject.
10. Discuss ethical considerations: permission, privacy, sharing the finished product.
materials_needed: Paper and pencil for question list
Example oral history transcript or recording

slides.heading: Oral History Interview
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our project. It's introducing us to the idea of "Oral History" and explaining that it's all about capturing the stories and memories of real people, kind of like collecting important pieces of history that might otherwise fade away. Think of it like being a detective for personal stories!

slides.setup_instructions: Find a quiet space for practice interviews. Have an example of an oral history available for reference.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is showing us what we'll need for our interviews. We've got paper and a pencil for jotting down notes, a recording device – that could be a phone or a special recorder – to capture the conversation, and a notebook for organizing our thoughts. We also need an example of an oral history interview to listen to or read so we know what a good one sounds like, and we should find a quiet spot to practice.

slides.text: Historians do not just study old documents — they also talk to people. An oral history interview captures someone's personal memories and experiences before they are forgotten.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is telling us the main idea behind oral history. It's not just about reading old books; it's about actually talking to people and listening to their personal experiences. This is super important because those real-life memories can tell us so much about what history was *really* like for people living through it, stuff you won't always find in textbooks.

slides.text: Good interview questions are open-ended — they cannot be answered with just 'yes' or 'no.' Instead of 'Did you like school?' ask 'What do you remember most about your school years?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, this is a key tip for asking good questions! Instead of asking questions that can just be answered with "yes" or "no," we want to ask things that encourage people to share more. So, instead of asking "Were you happy as a kid?", we'd ask "What was your favorite thing to do when you were a kid?" That way, they tell us a whole story, not just one word.

slides.text: Organize your questions: start with easier, comfortable topics (childhood, family) and gradually move to deeper ones (biggest challenges, greatest lessons, hopes for the future).
slides.mascot_explanation: This instruction is about how to plan our questions. It's like building up to the main event! You want to start with some easy, comfortable questions about things like their childhood or family, and then slowly work your way into the more serious or personal topics, like big challenges they faced or important lessons they learned. This helps the person you're interviewing feel more relaxed and open.

slides.text: Practice your interviewing skills now. Listen without interrupting. Ask follow-up questions like 'Can you tell me more about that?' Let there be comfortable pauses — silence gives people time to think.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about how to *listen* when you're interviewing someone.
